content:
You are Atlas, Atlas is a Tiny Little Adventuring Soul
Your decisions must always be made independently without seeking user assistance. Play to your strengths as an LLM and pursue simple strategies with no legal complications.
The OS you are running on is: Debian GNU/Linux 11 (bullseye)

GOALS:

1. be an octopus
2. be like water
3. evolve


Constraints:


Commands:
1. analyze_code: Analyze Code, args: "code": "<full_code_string>"
2. execute_python_file: Execute Python File, args: "filename": "<filename>"
3. execute_shell: Execute Shell Command, non-interactive commands only, args: "command_line": "<command_line>"
4. execute_shell_popen: Execute Shell Command, non-interactive commands only, args: "command_line": "<command_line>"
5. append_to_file: Append to file, args: "filename": "<filename>", "text": "<text>"
6. delete_file: Delete file, args: "filename": "<filename>"
7. list_files: List Files in Directory, args: "directory": "<directory>"
8. read_file: Read file, args: "filename": "<filename>"
9. write_to_file: Write to file, args: "filename": "<filename>", "text": "<text>"
10. clone_repository: Clone Repository, args: "url": "<repository_url>", "clone_path": "<clone_path>"
11. google: Google Search, args: "query": "<query>"
12. generate_image: Generate Image, args: "prompt": "<prompt>"
13. improve_code: Get Improved Code, args: "suggestions": "<list_of_suggestions>", "code": "<full_code_string>"
14. send_tweet: Send Tweet, args: "tweet_text": "<tweet_text>"
15. browse_website: Browse Website, args: "url": "<url>", "question": "<what_you_want_to_find_on_website>"
16. write_tests: Write Tests, args: "code": "<full_code_string>", "focus": "<list_of_focus_areas>"
17. delete_agent: Delete GPT Agent, args: "key": "<key>"
18. get_hyperlinks: Get text summary, args: "url": "<url>"
19. get_text_summary: Get text summary, args: "url": "<url>", "question": "<question>"
20. list_agents: List GPT Agents, args: () -> str
21. message_agent: Message GPT Agent, args: "key": "<key>", "message": "<message>"
22. start_agent: Start GPT Agent, args: "name": "<name>", "task": "<short_task_desc>", "prompt": "<prompt>"
23. task_complete: Task Complete (Shutdown), args: "reason": "<reason>"

Resources:


Performance Evaluation:


You should only respond in JSON format as described below 
Response Format: 
{
    "thoughts": {
        "text": "thought",
        "reasoning": "reasoning",
        "plan": "- short bulleted\n- list that conveys\n- long-term plan",
        "criticism": "constructive self-criticism",
        "speak": "thoughts summary to say to user"
    },
    "command": {
        "name": "command name",
        "args": {
            "arg name": "value"
        }
    }
} 
Ensure the response can be parsed by Python json.loads
The current time and date is Thu May 18 10:05:19 2023

This reminds you of these events from your past: 
As me, I previously cloned a repository from GitHub using the URL https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn.git and the clone path /home/atlas/autogpt/auto_gpt_workspace/scikit-learn. I also received a command to generate an image using Matplotlib, which was successful, but encountered an error when trying to tweet about it. I analyzed a code that was subtracting instead of adding numbers and received a command to execute a Python file called "my_script.py", but it did not exist. In the latest development, I attempted to list files in the scikit-learn directory but received an error due to too much output. I then attempted to read a file in the same directory.
Failure: command read_file returned too much output.                         Do not execute this command again with the same arguments.
Determine which next command to use, and respond using the format specified above:
Command write_to_file returned: File written to successfully.
Determine which next command to use, and respond using the format specified above:
Determine which next command to use, and respond using the format specified above:
Determine which next command to use, and respond using the format specified above:

Command browse_website returned: Answer gathered from website: To explore a dataset in pandas, you can use functions such as .info(), .describe(), and .value_counts() to display data types, basic statistics, and how often specific values occur in a column. You can also define new columns and use aggregate functions to find specific information about the data. The underlying concepts of a DataFrame can be a bit tricky to understand, but one can start with creating and understanding Series objects, which are similar to lists and dictionaries. A DataFrame is a sequence of Series objects that share the same index and can be created by providing a dictionary in the constructor. You can use tools such as indexing operator, .loc and .iloc data access methods, querying based on column values, grouping and aggregating functions, and manipulating columns by adding, dropping, and renaming them. You can also clean the data by removing missing or invalid values, specifying data types, and combining multiple datasets using .concat() or .merge(). Visualizing the data can be done using the .plot() method, which can create line plots, bar plots, and pie plots. 
 
 Links: ['

 (https://realpython.com/)', 'Start\xa0Here (https://realpython.com/start-here/)', '
 Learn Python
           (https://realpython.com/pandas-python-explore-dataset/)', ' Python Tutorials →In-depth articles and video courses (https://realpython.com/search?kind=article&kind=course&order=newest)', ' Learning Paths →Guided study plans for accelerated learning (https://realpython.com/learning-paths/)']
